title: Luther Blissett: Authorities must take harder stance on racism – if it happens again the match should be stopped
text:
Luther Blissett, the first black player to score a hat-trick for England, says Uefa must immediately haul the players off at Wembley next month against Montenegro if any more racist abuse is heard.

The former Watford striker, who faced derogatory chants throughout his career, also called on the Premier League and FA to beam video footage of those shouting abuse on big screens at domestic matches to shame those involved.

Monkey chants against players in Sofia on Monday was the second time during the Euro 2020 qualifying campaign that the likes of Raheem Sterling have faced severe abuse.

The Montenegrin association was ordered to play a match behind closed doors and fined €20,000 after its supporters were found guilty of racially abusing England players during a qualifier in March.

"We are now in a situation where if we hear any of it, we are going to stop the game," the 61-year-old said. Blissett, who was targeted by racists in Bulgaria while playing for England Under-21s in the 1970s, believes Uefa should have called the game off on Monday as abuse continued after Gareth Southgate twice highlighted that his players were coming under attack.
